qas.question: Diaphoresis causes a massive surge of what hormones?
Which nervous system is responsible for shortness of breath?
What is left ventricular failure called?
What kind of shock can cause sudden death?

context: Shortness of breath occurs when the damage to the heart limits the output of the left ventricle, causing left ventricular failure and consequent <b3_0>pulmonary edema<b3_0/>. Other symptoms include <b0_0>diaphoresis<b0_0/> (an excessive form of sweating), weakness, light-headedness, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations. These symptoms are likely induced by a massive surge of <b1_0>catecholamines<b1_0/> from the <b2_0>sympathetic<b2_0/> nervous system, which occurs in response to pain and the blood flow abnormalities that result from dysfunction of the heart muscle. Loss of consciousness (due to inadequate blood flow to the brain and <b4_0>cardiogenic<b4_0/> shock) and sudden death (frequently due to the development of ventricular fibrillation) can occur in MIs.
